awd_titl_txt: Plasma Photonics for the Control of Kilojoule Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project investigates the possibility of control of high-energy and high-power lasers using mirrors and other optics created with plasmas.  Continued advances in laser science have enabled the development of more energetic and more powerful lasers that can provide unprecedented access to ultrafast time scales and to temperatures and pressures once reserved for the Sun. The utility of these lasers is limited by conventional laser optics, typically made of glass, which break down under high incident laser energy flux. In order to support high-energy lasers using conventional materials, special large-aperture optics are required to reduce the energy per unit area.  The spatial limitations, complexity, and costs associated with such optics are a roadblock to the development and deployment of high-energy and high-peak-power lasers.  Plasma-based optical devices offer an alternative to the conventional optics because they are not limited by material breakdown.  The laser and x-ray technology enabled by plasma-based optical devices would be used in a wide range of applied research from materials science to biology to medicine.

Development of plasma-based photonic devices from proof-of-principle concepts to an enabling technology for next-generation lasers requires improved understanding of their performance capabilities and limitations. The highest-level objective of this research project is to understand the plasma physics of photonic devices by demonstrating and fully characterizing ellipsoidal plasma mirrors (EPMs) for implementation in kilojoule (kJ)-class laser systems to produce high-quality laser pulses with modified temporal durations, increased laser contrast, and controllable focusing geometry. This work will include a series of experiments with detailed measurements of both the EPM performance and its effect on the laser properties. The advantage of the EPM technology is that it can be employed in existing lasers systems to increase their performance without having to modify the laser infrastructure. EPMs are an excellent option to control the focusing of ultrashort-pulse (< 100 fs), kJ-class lasers and could enable the high intensities necessary to explore emerging high-field scientific areas such as quantum electrodynamics and attosecond science.  This award to support an undergraduate student is made under the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering and is complementary to a DOE award made under the joint program.

por.por_cntn:
Continued advances in laser technology have enabled the development of both higher-power and higher-energy lasers.  Lasers that combine high peak power and high energy will expand numerous scientific opportunities including relativistic plasma physics, astrophysics, and the fundamental physics of extreme electromagnetic fields interacting with matter.   

The utility of these lasers is limited by the existing optical technology.  Conventional laser optics break down under high incident laser fluence, and in order to support both high-power and high-energy lasers, expensive large-aperture optics are required to reduce the incident fluence.  The spatial limitations and costs associated with large-aperture optics are a roadblock to the development and deployment of such lasers and to the focused intensity that can be achieved.  The large optics also restrict experimental flexibility such as coupling these lasers to pulsed-power facilities, particle beams, or other lasers. 

Plasma-based photonic devices offer an alternative to large-aperture optics for high-power and high-energy lasers.  These photonic devices are not limited by material breakdown and therefore can support the laser fluences required in high-power and high-energy laser systems.  Developing these plasma photonic devices from proof-of-principle concepts to an enabling technology for next-generation lasers requires advancing these concepts so that their performance capabilities and limitations are understood and that their performance is optimized. 

The main goal of this project was to develop plasma photonic devices (plasma lenses or ellipsoidal plasma mirrors (EPMs)) for controlling the focus of high-energy (kJ-class) laser systems.  In order to defocus a kJ-class laser beam, a plasma optic must produce a very specific plasma density profile.  For a plasma lens, this profile must be peaked on axis and fall off parabolicly with radius.  We developed four plasma-lens target designs that were predicted to yield the ideal plasma profile required for defocusing kJ-class laser beams.  The resulting plasma lens must also be underdense, which sets an upper limit on the solid density of the plasma-lens targets to ~ 1 mg/cm3 or less.  This low of a density is highly challenging to fabricate.  We identified a path to the production of such targets via two-photon polymerization (TPP).  We established a collaboration with one of the premier TPP labs, Dr. Yongfeng Lu’s Laser Assisted Nano Engineering Group at the University of Nebraska Lincoln (UNL), for the manufacturing of these targets.  The extremely fine structure sizes involved in the plasma-lens targets (dimensions as small as 0.4 μm) also meant that new techniques had to be developed to ship and mount these targets. 

We secured 2 ½ shot days to test plasma lenses on the OMEGA EP laser.  During this shot time, we tested all variations of the plasma-lens target designs as well as two methods of heating the plasma-lens targets (direct irradiation with the laser and indirect heating with x-rays).  Measurements of the density and temperature evolution of the resulting plasma profile were taken as a function of time, laser intensity, laser spot size, and target diameter. 

In conjunction with the experiment work, we investigated plasma lens formation via Eulerian simulations in collaboration with Kirk Flippo’s group at Los Alamos National Laboratory.  These simulations were used to re-create the experimental conditions, and we found relatively good agreement between the experiment data and simulation results. 

We also completed a series of experiments on the OMEGA EP laser investigating what f/# and spot quality are ultimately needed for one of the immediate applications of plasma lenses—shaping kJ-class lasers to drive self-modulated laser wakefield acceleration (SMLWFA).  This work showed that the production of electron beams from SMLWFA-based laser plasma accelerators is strongly dependent on the quality of the laser focal spot.  For electron beams to be reliably produced, the laser spot needs to be round and centrally peaked.  We find that f/#s of 5 or longer work well. 

In addition to plasma lenses, ellipsoidal plasma mirrors (EPMs) were investigated as a means to control the focal geometry of kJ-class lasers.  The optical design code FRED was used to complete an initial design for an ellipsoidal optic to be the basis of an EPM.  Through this design process, we determined what type of focusing geometries could be achieved and demonstrated a design for a defocusing EPM. 

This project has advanced a female, early-career scientist to a leadership role.  As the Principle Investigator, she has gained visibility within the plasma photonics, plasma physics, material science, and target fabrication communities.  The PI has mentored three graduate students and supervised an undergraduate researcher as part of this project.  These students gained the skills needed to build and align laser diagnostics, and they learned how to run a multi-week experimental campaign on a small laser system as well a single-day campaign on a larger experimental facility.
